Now, the claim is that if a graph has such a circuit, then every vertex in the graph must have an even degree. Degree of a vertex is the number of edges connected to it.

To prove this, let's think about what happens when we traverse the Eulerian circuit.

Consider any vertex v in the graph. Every time the circuit passes through vertex v, it must enter through one edge and exit through another. That's because the circuit is continuous and doesn't stop at any vertex except the starting one at the end.

So, for each visit to vertex v, two edges are "used up": one for entering and one for exiting. Even if the circuit passes through v multiple times, each passage contributes two edges to the degree of v.
